text.p: The following are the reports carried by Estonia's newspapers on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these reports and does not vouch for their accuracy:
- Negotiations over the governing coalition have stopped until the ruling administration decides whether to broaden the alliance or continue in a minority government.
- Sentences for drug-connected crimes are too light in Estonia, with drug dealers given only probationary sentences, a report by the International Narcotics Control Bureau claims.
- The shares that the state owns in the central Tallinn Hotel Olympia are to be sold and the operating firm of the hotel have first refusal in buying.

- Former German foreign minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher and former Danish foreign minister Uffe Ellemann-Jensen were made honorary members of Tartu University for their support in creating a Euro-faculty.
- Prisoners who received life sentences should be detained in solitary cells but no money has been allocated for this.
- The Baltic states should be among the countries that are admitted to the European Union and NATO in the first round, Uffe Ellemann-Jensen said as he has made an honorary member of Tartu University.
- Passport checking at the Estonian-Finnish border will not be stopped but strengthened when visa free travel between the countries comes into force.
- Progress in land reform is still too slow, with only 13 percent of the land entered in the land register, officials said.
- Estonian Union Bank will offer a new service for its clients from next week, to deposit privatisation vouchers with 2.2 percent annual interest, paid in cash, bank leaders said.
